Dry season (November to April) is when the tourist season surges. The weather is warm and sunny with minimal rainfall. However, off-peak seasons in May and October and December and January can be less packed and less priced.

What to Do in the Maldives

Island Hopping: Different islands, each having a unique charm and attractions.
Water Sports: snorkeling, diving, and jet skiing.
Spa Treatments: Experience various types of spa treatments for the ultimate relaxation and rejuvenation.
Sunset Cruises: Enjoy a romantical sunset cruise with breathtaking views.
Visit Local Islands: Respect the local culture and lifestyle by visiting their island.

Tips to Book Your Trip

Choose Your Accommodation: Decide between a luxury resort or a budget-friendly guesthouse.
Book Activities in Advance: Popular activities like diving and snorkeling can book up quickly.
Pack Light: Bring essentials like swimwear, sunscreen, and a hat.
Respect the Local Culture: Dress appropriately when island-hopping.
Take the Underwater Tour: Do not miss the chance to see the beautiful marine life.

Paradise Awaits: Book Your Maldives Luxury Vacation Now

The Maldives is an unforgettable retreat for travelers who seek luxury, relaxation, and adventure. Whether it's a honeymoon, family holiday, or a solo trip, the Maldives has something for everyone. Start planning your dream vacation today!

fields.title: MAURITIUS
fields.content:
Mauritius, an island nation in the Indian Ocean, is a real treasure with fabulous luxury, adventure, and natural beauty. With pristine beaches, lush rainforests, and a vibrant culture, Mauritius has been a dream destination for many travelers.

Why Visit Mauritius?

Breathtaking Beaches: Mauritius has some of the world's most beautiful beaches with soft white sand and crystal-clear turquoise waters.
Culture: The island has a great diversity of cultures with influences from Africa, India, and Europe.
Water Sports: The island offers water sports ranging from diving and snorkeling to kite surfing and windsurfing.
Luxurious Resorts: The island boasts world-class resorts that are equipped with everything, including overwater bungalows and spa treatments.
Natural Beauty: Explore the lush rainforests, cascading waterfalls, and volcanic craters.

Best time to visit:

The best time to visit Mauritius is during the dry season, from May to November. The weather is warm and sunny, with minimal rainfall.

Things to Do in Mauritius:

Island Hopping :Explore the nearby islands of Ile aux Cerfs and Ile aux Aigrettes.
Water Sports :Dive, snorkel, kite surf, and windsurf in the crystal-clear waters.
Hiking and Trekking :Hike through the Black River Gorges National Park.
Cultural Experiences: Explore local markets, temples, and historical sites.
Relaxation: Enjoy the beach and spa treatments, indulge in Mauritian cuisine.

Tips for Planning Your Trip:

Book Your Accommodation in Advance: Popular resorts and hotels often sell out soon, especially during peak season.
Pack for the Weather: Don't forget sunscreen, a hat, and comfy clothing.
Learn a Few Basic Phrases in Creole: This will help you interact with locals.
Respect Local Traditions: Dress modestly when going to the religious locations.
Try the Food of the Locals: Mauritian cuisine is a delectable mix of Indian, Chinese, and French influences.

Ready to Experience the Magic of Mauritius?

Mauritius is really an unforgettable destination. With its incredible natural beauty, rich culture, and excellent resorts, it is no wonder that it is a most favorite for honeymooners as well as families.

fields.title: SANTORINI
fields.content:
Santorini is one of the most visited tourist destinations in Greece. The island, a volcanic island in the Aegean Sea, boasts of a breathtaking caldera, whitewashed buildings, and dramatic sunsets that have captivated visitors for centuries.

Why Visit Santorini?

Picturesque Villages: Discover quaint villages like Oia, Fira, and Imerovigli with breathtaking views of the caldera.
Volcanic Beaches: Enjoy the unique black, red, and white sand beaches.
Delicious Cuisine: Fresh seafood, local wines, and traditional Greek dishes.
Romantic Atmosphere: Santorini is very honeymoon-friendly, promising a romantic, very idyllic atmosphere.
Cultural Experiences: Ancient ruins, art galleries, museums

Best Time to Visit:

The summer is the peak tourist season, extending from June to August. Not surprisingly, the shoulder months of April-May and September-October enjoy pleasant weather and fewer crowds .

Things to Do in Santorini:

Caldera Rim: Hike to explore the caldera rim.
Ancient Thira: See the ancient ruins of the city of Thira.
Wine tasting: Explore some of the many wine-producing vineyards and sample their wares.
Boat Trips: Visit the islands close to Santorini by taking a boat trip out to the islands of Thirassia and Nea Kameni.
Sun, Swim and Beach Life: Simply enjoy a day relaxing sunbathing and swimming in one of the beaches.

Hints on How to Plan for Your Visit:

Book your accommodation in advance: The popular hotels and villas can book up very fast, especially during peak season.
Pack light: Bring comfortable clothing and a light jacket for cooler evenings.
Rent a car or scooter: This is the best way to explore the island at your own pace.
Try local cuisine: Do not miss the opportunity to savor delicious Greek food.
Capture the sunset: Find a spot with a stunning view and watch the sunset.

Are you ready to live the magic of Santorini?

A true gem for all times, Santorini blends history, culture, and nature in a truly unique blend that will offer anything you want-from romance, adventure, to complete relaxation.

Santorini, a volcanic island in the Aegean Sea, is one of the most popular tourist destinations in Greece. Its stunning caldera, whitewashed buildings, and breathtaking sunsets have captivated visitors for centuries.

Why Visit Santorini?

Picturesque Villages: Explore charming villages like Oia, Fira, and Imerovigli, with their stunning views of the caldera.
Volcanic Beaches: Relax on the unique black, red, and white sand beaches.
Delicious Cuisine: Savor fresh seafood, local wines, and traditional Greek dishes.
Romantic Atmosphere: Santorini is a popular honeymoon destination, offering a romantic and idyllic setting.
Cultural Experiences: Visit ancient ruins, art galleries, and museums.

Best Time to Visit:

The peak tourist season in Santorini is during the summer months (June to August). However, the shoulder seasons (April-May and September-October) offer pleasant weather and fewer crowds.

Things to Do in Santorini:

Explore the Caldera: Hike along the caldera rim, taking in the breathtaking views.
Visit Ancient Thira: Discover the ruins of the ancient city of Thira.
Wine Tasting: Sample local wines at one of the many vineyards.
Boat Tours: Take a boat trip to nearby islands, such as Thirassia and Nea Kameni.
Relax on the Beach: Spend a day sunbathing and swimming on the beautiful beaches.

Tips for Planning Your Trip:

Book Accommodation in Advance: Popular hotels and villas can book up quickly, especially during peak season.
Pack Light: Bring comfortable clothing and a light jacket for cooler evenings.
Rent a Car or Scooter: This is the best way to explore the island at your own pace.
Try Local Cuisine: Don't miss the opportunity to savor delicious Greek food.
Capture the Sunset: Find a spot with a stunning view and watch the sunset.

Ready to Experience the Magic of Santorini?

Santorini is a truly magical place that offers a unique blend of history, culture, and natural beauty. Whether you're seeking romance, adventure, or relaxation, Santorini has something for everyone.

fields.title: SVALBARD
fields.content:
Svalbard, the Norwegian archipelago nestled deep in the Arctic Ocean, is a land of extreme beauty and conditions. The landscape of this destination is breathtakingly beautiful and teeming with unique wildlife, including scientific research stations, to be an unforgettable adventure for adventurous travelers.

Why Svalbard?

Polar Bear Capital: Svalbard houses an abundant number of polar bears that have been making it a dream destination of the wildlife enthusiasts.

Midnight Sun and Polar Night: Experience the midnight sun phenomenon, where the sun shines 24 hours of the day, or polar night, where the sun does not rise for months.

Stunning Landscapes: From towering glaciers and snow-capped mountains to colorful Arctic flora, the landscapes of Svalbard are truly breathtaking.

Northern Lights: You can witness the Northern Lights dancing in the night sky during winter months.

Unique Culture: Discover the interesting history and culture of the Svalbard community, from unique laws to special regulations.

Best Time to Visit

The best time to visit Svalbard depends on your interests:

Summer (June-August): The perfect time for wildlife watching, hiking, and enjoying the midnight sun.
Winter (December-March): Perfect for Northern Lights sightings, dog sledding, and snowmobiling.

Things to Do in Svalbard

Polar Bear Safaris by boat or snowmobile to get thrilling experiences.
Dog Sledding: Experience an Arctic wilderness dog sled.
Hike and Trek: Witness the beautiful landscapes at your feet.
Northern Light Hunting: Chase the enigmatic Aurora Borealis.
Visit a Research Station: Learn about scientific research in the Arctic.
Kayaking: Paddle along the pristine waters of the Arctic Ocean.
Bird Watching: Observe various bird species of the Arctic.

Visit Svalbard: Tips and Essentials

Pack Warm: The climate is arctic, so pack warm, waterproof clothing.
Respect Wildlife: Maintain a distance from wildlife, especially the polar bears.
Hire a Guide: Locals can add to an experience and ensure your safety too.
Plan Ahead: Book hotels and activities in advance as well, especially during the peak seasons.
Travel Insurance: Get travel insurance as comprehensive as possible to make sure that anything unexpected is taken care of.

Svalbard is an utterly unique destination with experiences that cannot be forgotten. Follow these tips and prepare well for your trip, and you'll get the best of your stay in this Arctic paradise.

fields.title: HAVANA
fields.content:
Havana, the vibrant capital of Cuba, is a captivating city steeped in history, culture, and a unique charm. With its colorful colonial buildings, classic cars, and lively music scene, Havana offers a glimpse into the past while embracing the present.

Why Visit Havana?

Colonial Architecture: Admire the stunning Spanish colonial architecture, including the historic center of Old Havana.
Classic Cars: Enjoy the city ride in a vintage American car that represents the uniqueness of Havana.
Music and Dance: The lively music scene, from traditional Cuban son to modern salsa and jazz, is another attraction.
Historic Sites: Visit the famous sites, such as the Castillo del Morro, Plaza de la Revolución, and the Malecón.
Beaches: Enjoy the wonderful beaches of Varadero or Playa del Este.

Best Time to Visit

The best time to visit Havana is during the dry season, November to April. It's pleasant weather, and not very crowded.

Things to Do in Havana

Walk down the cobblestone streets of Old Havana, view its colorful colonial buildings, and visit such historic places as the Plaza de la Catedral and the Castillo del Morro.
Ride in a Classic Car: Experience Havana's famous classic cars firsthand. Have a fun ride around the city and enjoy unforgettable moments.
Enjoy Cuban Music and Dance: Feel the pulsation of music by attending live performance or participating in dance class.
Visit the Malecón: Walk on Malecón, the seawall of Havana, to witness the scenic ocean views.
Relax on the Beach: Get out of the city and relax on the gorgeous beaches of Varadero or Playa del Este.
Try Cuban Cuisine: Enjoy some great Cuban food like ropa vieja, arroz con frijoles, and lechon asado.
Visit Local Markets: Check out local markets to get unique souvenirs and handicrafts.

Tips for Visiting Havana

Learn Basic Spanish: It is helpful to know a few basic Spanish phrases.
Bring Cash: Credit cards are not as commonly accepted so bring enough cash.
Respect Local Customs: Respect the local customs and traditions.
Hydration: The tropical climate can be hot and humid, so keep hydrating.
Bargain at Markets: Don't hesitate to haggle for a good price at local markets.

Havana is a city that will catch the senses and leave you with memories that will last forever. With these tips and with an understanding of the culture, you can really enjoy the magic of this dynamic city.

fields.title: AMSTERDAM
fields.content:
Amsterdam is the capital city of the Netherlands. The city balances perfectly well its historical past with artistic expressions and modern cultures. It boasts of lovely canals, quaint bridges, and excellent museums, which makes it one of the world's top tourist destinations. 

Must-see Attractions

Rijksmuseum: Be transported through the history of Dutch art within the walls of this prominent museum, home to such works by Rembrandt, Vermeer, and Frans Hals.
Van Gogh Museum: Find out more about the legendary artist Vincent van Gogh's life and work through paintings, drawings, and his letters.
Anne Frank House: Go back in history and experience the tragic history of Anne Frank during the World War.
Canal Cruise: Relax on a leisurely boat cruise along the city's ancient canals, admiring the grand beauty of the architecture and bridges.
Vondelpark: Unwind in this vast urban park- the perfect place for picnics, cycling, or simply watching people pass.

Gastronomic Delights

Dutch Pancakes: Enjoy fluffy poffertjes or hearty pannekoeken with various sweet and savory toppings.
Herring: Savor the famous raw herring, a Dutch specialty that is traditionally consumed with onions and pickles.
Stroopwafels: Yummy caramel waffles cannot be missed and are super delicious for a quick bite or dessert.
Dutch Cheese: Explore cheese market to taste Gouda, Edam, Maasdam, and others.
Bike Tour: Rent a bike and roam the city like a local, cycling through the neat neighborhoods and along the canals.
Red Light District: Though controversy, a visit to the Red Light District gives insight into the other side of the culture in Amsterdam.
Coffee Shops: Take in one of Amsterdam's liberal lifestyle options in one of its coffee shops, where cannabis is legally sold.
Flower Market: Visit the Bloemenmarkt, one of the world's oldest floating flower markets, and admire its vibrant flowers and unique plants.

Useful Information for Your Visit

Purchase a City Card: This convenience card offers discounts on public transport, museums, and attraction entrance fees.
Learn Simple Dutch Phrases: Basic simple phrases will make the rest of your trip far easier.
Respect Neighborhood Cultures: Respect local neighborhood culture and customs, which vary in quiet neighborhoods
Dress for the Weather: Amsterdam's weather changes all at once, so make sure to dress in layers as rain can be expected to drop at any time

Amsterdam is a city that offers something for everyone. Whether you're interested in art, history, or simply enjoying the city's vibrant atmosphere, you're sure to have an unforgettable experience. With its picturesque canals, world-class museums, and delicious cuisine, Amsterdam is a must-visit destination.

fields.title: NEW ORLEANS
fields.content:
New Orleans, affectionately called "NOLA," is a city that effortlessly blends history, music, and culinary delights. This vibrant city offers a truly unforgettable experience with its unique blend of French, African, and Caribbean influences.

Must-See Attractions

French Quarter: Immerse yourself in the heart of New Orleans, where colorful buildings, lively bars, and historic landmarks line the streets.
Bourbon Street: Enjoy the city's nightlife, with live music, street performers, and a plethora of bars and restaurants.
Jackson Square: View the impressive St. Louis Cathedral, local art, and enjoy some live music.
Garden District: Visit this beautiful neighborhood, full of gorgeous mansions and gardens.
City Park: Unwind in this vast park, which houses the New Orleans Museum of Art and the New Orleans Botanical Garden.

Culinary Delights

Cajun and Creole Cuisine: Indulge in the rich flavors of New Orleans' signature dishes, including gumbo, jambalaya, and po' boys.
Beignets: Savor these delicious fried pastries, dusted with powdered sugar, at iconic spots like Café du Monde.
Seafood: Fresh seafood is a staple in New Orleans, with dishes like oysters Rockefeller, shrimp and grits, and crawfish étouffée.

Music and Culture

Jazz Music: Visit places like Preservation Hall and the Blue Nile to experience the birthplace of jazz.
Mardi Gras: Celebrate with this famous carnival, complete with parades, costumes, and lively street parties.
Voodoo Culture: Discover spiritual traditions of the city and take in some of the historic places such as the Voodoo Spiritual Temple.

Tips for Your Visit

Best Time to Visit: Spring and Fall are wonderful seasons with pleasant weather, less crowded.
Transportation: Walking is the best way to explore the French Quarter and other neighborhoods. Streetcars and taxis are also convenient options.
Safety: New Orleans is generally safe, but it would not be wrong to exercise caution-especially at night.
Local Customs: Respect local customs and traditions, particularly during religious events.

New Orleans is a city that captures one's soul. Its meld of cultures, music, and food could not help but make New Orleans memorable. You can explore the historic French Quarter, indulge in delectable food, or experience its nightlife-in any of these activities, you are bound to have a good time.

fields.title: WAIKATO
fields.content:
Nestled in the heart of New Zealand's North Island, Waikato is a very enticing combination of natural beauty, cultural heritage, and exciting adventure. Largely overshadowed by its more famous neighbors, Waikato provides the adventurous traveler with a fresh, exciting, and very rewarding experience for those wanting off-the-beaten-path destinations.

Discovering Waikato's Diverse Landscapes

The Mighty Waikato River: The longest river in New Zealand, the Waikato River winds its way through the region, offering opportunities for kayaking, fishing, and scenic cruises.

The Picturesque Waitomo Caves: Descend into the mystical underground of the Waitomo Caves, where thousands of glowworms illuminate the limestone caverns, creating an entrancing spectacle.

The Geothermal Wonders of Rotorua: Just a short drive away, Rotorua offers a glimpse into New Zealand's volcanic past. Experience bubbling mud pools, steaming geysers, and Maori cultural performances.

Adventures for the Thrill-Seeker

White-Water Rafting on the Kaituna River: For adrenaline junkies, the Kaituna River offers exhilarating white-water rafting experiences, including the world's highest commercially rafted waterfall.

Mountain Bike in the Kaimai Ranges: Hike, pedal through a challenging area rich with wildlife and a wild feel while mountain biking to take it to the next level in a rugged landscape through the Kaimai ranges. Choose from easy paths or all-day adventure and suitable to various skill levels.

Maori Culture: Learn of the rich history and traditions of the Maori people at the cultural villages and performances throughout the region.

Hamilton Gardens: Discover a world of diverse gardens in Hamilton Gardens, from formal English gardens to exotic Asian landscapes.

Practical Tips for Your Waikato Adventure

Best Time to Visit:  The best time to visit Waikato is during the summer months (December to February) when the weather is warm and dry.
Getting There: Waikato is very accessible by car or bus from Auckland.
Accommodation: There are lots of accommodation options ranging from the budget hostels to the luxury lodges.
Food: Enjoy the local specialties, such as fresh seafood, lamb-based dishes, and world-class wines.

A little-known gem, Waikato offers a unique blend of natural beauty, cultural experiences, and outdoor adventures. Whether you seek relaxation, excitement, or something in between, the region of Waikato offers it all.

fields.title: LONDON HARRY POTTER STUDIO
fields.content:
As a lifelong Harry Potter enthusiast, entering Warner Bros. Studio Tour London was literally entering a dream. An immersive experience will take you behind the scenes of an iconic film series, exposing the magic, creativity, and sheer hard work that gave life to the wizarding world.

The Great Hall

The tour starts in the impressive Great Hall, the epitome of beauty: an imposing hall with floating hundreds of candles and magic on the ceiling. Precise tables with feasts taken away will take you to the heart of Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry.

Diagon Alley

Then you walk down Diagon Alley, filled with shops such as Ollivander's Wand Shop, Weasleys' Wizard Wheezes, and Gringotts Wizarding Bank. It's really incredible how much detail was paid to bring this place into life from the books.

Forbidden Forest

You step into the Forbidden Forest, full of towering trees and eerie creatures and the legendary Aragog. The size of the creatures and the beauty of the set make you feel you are actually inside the books.

Hogwarts Express

All aboard the Hogwarts Express! Board the iconic train and relive the magical journey from King's Cross Station to Hogwarts. Attention to detail is impressive, from luggage racks to windows.

Magic Behind the Scenes

Learn all the interesting aspects of the filmmaking process that took place during the making of the wizarding world. Discover the special effects, costume design, and prop making that brought this fantasy world to life. You can even try on a Sorting Hat and wave a magic wand!

A must-visit for all Potterheads!

Warner Bros. Studio Tour London is a must for any Harry Potter fan. Whether you are a die-hard Potterhead or just curious about the magic of filmmaking, this immersive experience will leave you spellbound.

Tips for Your Visit:

Book in advance: Tickets sell out quickly, so be sure to book your visit well in advance.
Wear comfortable shoes: The tour involves a lot of walking.
Come early: This will help you have ample time in exploring the exhibits and beating crowds.
Bring your camera: Capture the magic of the wizarding world.
Feel the magic: Your imagination is free to run as you immerse yourself into the experience.

fields.title: CHERRAPUNJI
fields.content:
Lying within the lush, green hills of Meghalaya, Cherrapunji, also commonly known as Sohra, stands out to be a scenic wonder with unprecedented rainfall. Dubbed as one of the wettest places on the earth, this beautiful hill station presents an experience one has always dreamed of or been to as a lover for nature and adventure.

Why visit Cherrapunji?

Living Root Bridges: Walk across the ancient living root bridges, intricately woven by the Khasi people over centuries, a marvel of nature.

Majestic Waterfalls: Immerse yourself in the cascading beauty of Nohkalikai Falls, one of the tallest plunge waterfalls in India, and marvel at the awe-inspiring power of nature.

Serene Caves: Explore the mysterious depths of the Mawsmai Caves, adorned with stunning stalactite and stalagmite formations.

Picturesque Landscapes: Hike through verdant valleys, enjoy the stunning views of the surrounding hills, and capture the essence of this enchanting place.

Best Time to Visit

The best time to visit Cherrapunji is during the dry season from October to May. Even though the monsoon season from June to September brings heavy rainfall, the landscape is transformed into a lush green paradise.

How to Reach Cherrapunji

By Air: The nearest airport is Shillong Airport, 60 km from Cherrapunji.
By Train: The nearest railway station is Guwahati Railway Station, 180 km from Cherrapunji.
By Road: Cherrapunji is accessible by road from Shillong and Guwahati.

Where to Stay

There are various accommodations available at Cherrapunji ranging from home stay, resorts, etc. with every budget in mind.

Things to Know

Pack for the Weather: Be prepared for unpredictable weather, especially during the monsoon season. Pack rain gear, warm clothing, and comfortable footwear.
Respect the Local Culture: Cherrapunji is home to the Khasi tribe, known for their rich cultural heritage. Respect their customs and traditions.
Hire a Local Guide: A local guide can provide valuable insights into the history, culture, and natural wonders of Cherrapunji.


Cherrapunji is one of the hidden gems of northeast India, which presents a combination of natural beauty, cultural heritage, and adventure activities. Whether you seek calmness, adventure, or just a view that breathes life into you, Cherrapunji is for everyone.

fields.title: VISAKHAPATNAM
fields.content:
Visakhapatnam, affectionately called Vizag, is a captivating coastal city in the Indian state of Andhra Pradesh. Nestled on the Bay of Bengal, it offers a delightful blend of natural beauty, historical significance, and vibrant culture. Whether you're a beach lover, history enthusiast, or simply seeking a tranquil getaway, Vizag has something for everyone.

Discovering Vizag's Natural Wonders

Beaches:

Rushikonda Beach: This pristine beach, with its golden sands and clear waters, is a haven for sunbathers and water sports enthusiasts.
Ramakrishna Beach: Known for its scenic beauty and cleanliness, Ramakrishna Beach offers a relaxing atmosphere and stunning views of the Bay of Bengal.
Yarada Beach: This secluded beach, with its serene ambiance, is perfect for those seeking solitude and tranquility.

Hills:
Kailashgiri: This hilltop park affords a panoramic view of the city and the sea. It has beautiful gardens, statues, and a cable car ride to the top.
Dolphin's Nose: This rock formation is popularly known as Dolphin's Nose because it is shaped like a dolphin's nose. Many people come here for trekking and picnics.

Immersed in History and Culture

Kailasa Temple: This ancient Hindu temple is carved out of a single rock and is a masterpiece in Dravidian architecture.
Kursura Submarine Museum: Explore the deep into the sea at this unique museum housed inside a decommissioned submarine.
Vizag Port: Witness the hubbub of one of the busiest ports in India as ships from all over the world dock.

A Treat for the Taste Buds

From Vizag's varied taste bud pleasure of pure Andhra traditions to a variety of cuisines across the world, food lovers here can have some really tasteful moments savoring the delectable fish and prawns in one of its seafood dishes curries.

Tips for Your Visit:

Best Time to Visit: October to March is ideal to visit Vizag when pleasant weather is seen to provide an ideal experience for activities outdoors.
How to Get There: Vizag is well connected by air, rail, and road. The city has its own international airport and a major railway station.
Getting Around: The best way to get around the city is to rent a two-wheeler or hire an auto-rickshaw.
Accommodation: Vizag offers a wide range of accommodation options, ranging from budget-friendly guesthouses to luxurious hotels.

Visakhapatnam is an integral part of nature where historical events, along with cultural dynamism, have molded it beautifully. Its beautiful beaches and scintillating hill tops with amiable and friendly people would promise memories to any visitor. Come and carry on a vacation in this paradise by the bay!

fields.title: KODAIKANAL
fields.content:
A very pretty hill station that boasts of a peaceful sojourn away from city life, Kodaikanal lies beautifully nestled in the Palani range of Tamil Nadu in India. Known for years as the "Princess of Hill Stations," the place is simply fascinating by its sceneries of breathtaking beauty, salubrious climate, and beautiful architecture all reminiscent of the colonial period.

Few highlights of a trip to Kodaikanal:

Nature's Hug

Kodaikanal Lake: A picturesque artificial lake surrounded by lush greenery, offering boating, horse riding, and leisurely walks.
Coaker's Walk: A scenic viewpoint offering panoramic vistas of the valley.
Dolphin's Nose: A rocky promontory shaped like a dolphin's nose, providing stunning views.
Bear Shola Falls: A cascading waterfall amidst dense forests, perfect for a refreshing hike.
Pillar Rocks: A unique rock formation with three massive pillars, offering a challenging climb.

Cultural Experiences:

Kodaikanal Solar Observatory: Uncover the secrets of the universe here.
Shenbaganur Museum: Learn more about the history and marvels of nature through amazing exhibits.
Kurinji Andavar Temple: This old temple dedicated to Lord Murugan is famous for its festivals.
Local Cuisine: Try local food - authentic South Indian dishes - and juicy fruits grown around.
Do not forget trying Kodaikanal chocolates; it is not a place for visitors without chocolate tasting.

Choose from a range of accommodations, from budget-friendly guesthouses to luxurious resorts.

Tips for Planning Your Trip:

Best time to visit: October to May offer pleasant weather.
Transport: Reaching Kodaikanal by road or air. Nearest airport is at Madurai. Taxis, buses, and auto-rickshaws can be used for local transportation.
What to pack: Comfortable shoes for walking, light clothes for warm days, and a jacket for cooler evenings.
Dress modestly when visiting religious sites.

Kodaikanal is one experience that would leave a lifelong mark in the hearts of all lovers of nature, adventure, and seclusion. Experience its bountiful beauty and enjoy wonderful moments for a lifetime.

fields.title: BANGALORE
fields.content:
Bangalore is India's "Silicon Valley." It's a city with rich heritage blended in with dynamic modernity. 

For the Culture Enthusiast:

Visit the Bangalore Palace: This palace, inspired by Windsor Castle, gives a glimpse of the grandeur of the Wodeyar dynasty. Explore its ornate interiors, sprawling gardens, and fascinating museum.
Dive into history at Tipu Sultan's Fort: Step back in time at this 16th-century fort, which witnessed the rise and fall of various dynasties. Explore its impressive ramparts, underground chambers, and the Gumbaz, a magnificent mausoleum.
Experience the serenity of ISKCON Temple: This beautiful temple dedicated to Lord Krishna is known for its intricate carvings, vibrant colors, and peaceful ambiance. Attend a devotional service or simply enjoy the serene surroundings.

For the Nature Lover:

Explore the lush greenery of Lalbagh Botanical Garden: This sprawling garden houses a collection of plants with a magnificent banyan tree. Take a leisurely stroll, visit the glasshouse, and enjoy the peaceful atmosphere.
Hike or bike through Cubbon Park: This urban oasis is a welcome break from the city's hustle and bustle. Enjoy the shade of ancient trees, visit the Bangalore Aquarium, and admire the Victorian-era bandstand.
Discover the beauty of Bannerghatta National Park: Take a wildlife safari and see elephants, tigers, bears, and other interesting creatures in their natural habitat.

For the Foodie:

Enjoy authentic South Indian cuisine: Bangalore is a foodie's paradise, offering a wide variety of delicious dishes. Don't miss the opportunity to savor dosas, idlis, vadas, and filter coffee.
Discover the eclectic food scene: From street stalls to high-end restaurants, the city of Bangalore offers a kaleidoscope of culinary delights. Try local fare, international options, and modern fusion.
See the vibrant markets: Explore Bangalore's markets with their colors and sounds. This is where spices, fresh fruits and vegetables, and local handicrafts are bought.

Bangalore trip tips

Best time to visit: October to March is the best time to visit Bangalore as the climate is comfortable, and it rains less.
Getting around: Bangalore has a good public transport system. There are buses and the metro. You can also hire auto-rickshaws or taxis.
Accommodation: You have a wide range of hotels, guesthouses, and homestays that can be booked according to your budget and preferences.

This is just a glimpse of what Bangalore has to offer. Embrace the city's vibrant energy, explore its hidden gems, and create unforgettable memories.

fields.title: DHANUSHKODI
fields.content:
Dhanushkodi, a fishing village on the southernmost end of India, has an undeniable charm. A once-thriving town, it was destroyed in 1964 by a cyclone, and the remnants speak of the devastations caused by nature. Now, it remains a ghost town, visited by tourists to view its mysterious past.

A Sojourn in Time:

The journey to Dhanushkodi itself is an adventure. The road winds through scenic landscapes, offering glimpses of the vast Indian Ocean. As you approach the village, the remnants of its former life begin to emerge – crumbling buildings, abandoned railway tracks, and a solitary church.

Explore the Ruins:

The Church: A miracle of survival, in the midst of the cyclone, the St. Anthony's Church stood intact. Weathered walls with stained-glass windows have their haunting contrast against the desolate landscape.
The Railway Station: The abandoned railway station with its rusted tracks merge into the horizon is a haunting reminder of the lost glory of the town.
Walk the abandoned streets of this ghost town and imagine how once-vibrant life flourished. Overgrown weeds with crumbling buildings stand like eerie apparitions amidst an atmosphere so surreal.

The End: Beauty in Ruin

Despite its tragic history, Dhanushkodi has a beauty that cannot be denied. The Bay of Bengal and Indian Ocean meet here in a dramatic landscape where waves crash against the shore with such force. The stretch of the sea is so long that it's breathtaking to look at.

Tips for Your Visit:

Best Time to Visit: October to March is the best time to visit Dhanushkodi, with cool temperatures and least rainfall.
Dhanushkodi can be reached from Rameswaram by road. Jeeps and auto-rickshaws are available for hiring.
Respect the Ruins: Please handle the ruins with respect and refrain from disturbing the artifacts.
Carry Essentials: Carry water, sunscreen, and a hat since it can get quite hot and sunny.

A Journey Beyond the Ruins:

Dhanushkodi is more than a ghost town. It's a place to connect with nature, reflect on the past, and appreciate the power of the elements. Whether it's for its historical significance or raw beauty, a visit to Dhanushkodi is an unforgettable experience.

fields.title: CALICUT
fields.content:
Day 1:

Morning: Tali Temple - This 12th-century Hindu temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva. The intricacy of architecture and the calm atmosphere make for a great way to start your day.
Mid-morning: Krishna Menon Museum - It is dedicated to the life and work of V.K. Krishna Menon, a prominent Indian statesman.
Afternoon: Visit Kappad Beach. It is where Vasco da Gama first set foot in India in 1498. Enjoy the beach and sunbath.  
Evening: Relax on the Kozhikode Beach and savor mouthwatering seafood at a beach restaurant.  

Day 2

Morning: First thing in the morning, head to Pazhassi Raja Museum. The Pazhassi Raja Museum is dedicated to the legendary warrior king, Pazhassi Raja.
Mid-morning: Explore the Sarovaram Bio Park, a beautiful botanical garden with a variety of flora and fauna.   
Afternoon: Visit the Beypore Beach, known for its traditional wooden shipbuilding industry. Take a boat ride on the Beypore River and enjoy the scenic views.   
Evening: Enjoy a traditional Kathakali dance performance at the Kerala Tourism Cultural Centre.

Day 3:
Morning: Visit Mananchira Square, a popular public park in the heart of the city. Feel the lively atmosphere and the beautiful fountain.   
Mid-morning: Take a visit to the Kozhikode Regional Science Centre and Planetarium, a place to learn more about science and astronomy.  
Afternoon: Visit the Thusharagiri Waterfalls, a waterfall located about 40 km from Kozhikode.
Evening: Dine at a restaurant in Kozhikode in the evening over a delicious seafood dinner and enjoy your wonderful trip.

Optional Activities:

Take a sun set stroll at the Kozhikode Beach.
Take a cooking class and try the local dishes of Kerala.
Shop for spices and handicrafts at the market in Kozhikode.
Visit Thikkoti Lighthouse for its stunning views of the city.
Visit the surrounding town of Wayanad for its beautiful sceneries and wildlife.  

Tips
Best time to visit Kozhikode is during October and March as the weather is good.   
Always bargain while shopping at the local markets.
Pick up some basic Malayalam words to interact with the locals.
Dress modestly while visiting religious sites.
Carry cash as credit cards are not accepted everywhere.
Have a great trip to Kozhikode!

fields.title: COCHIN
fields.content:
Cochin

Coastal city in Kerala, India, Cochin is a heady mix of history, culture, and natural beauty.

Day 1: Arrival & Old World Charm

Morning: Arrive at Cochin International Airport (COK). Check into your hotel.
Afternoon:
Fort Kochi: Explore the historic Fort Kochi area. Visit St. Francis Church (the oldest European church in India), Santa Cruz Basilica, and the Dutch Palace (Mattancherry Palace).
Chinese Fishing Nets: Take in the picturesque views of the iconic Chinese fishing nets at the harbor.
Spice Market: Breathe in the spice scents and see the local market.

Day 2: Backwaters & Beauty
Morning: Enjoy a gentle backwater cruise. Savor the views of the Kerala backwaters, lush green surroundings, and life in the village.
Afternoon:
Kumarakom Bird Sanctuary: (Optional) Visit this haven for bird enthusiasts that has various avian species.
Relaxation: Treat yourself to an Ayurvedic massage or take a leisurely walk on the beach.

Day 3: Art & History
Morning:
Jewish Synagogue: Visit the ancient Synagogue, a testament to Cochin's rich Jewish heritage.
Hill Palace Museum: Explore this sprawling museum showcasing Kerala's history and artifacts.
Afternoon:
Kathakali Performance: (Optional) Experience the mesmerizing Kathakali dance, a traditional art form of Kerala.
Shopping: Browse through local shops for souvenirs, handicrafts, and spices.

Day 4: Departure
Morning: Enjoy a leisurely breakfast and soak in the last moments of Cochin.
Afternoon: Depart from Cochin International Airport (COK).

Tips for your Blog:

Food: Don't miss the delicious seafood! Try local delicacies like Karimeen Pollichathu (fish baked in banana leaf) and Appam with Idiyappam.
Explore the local cafes and restaurants for authentic Kerala cuisine.

Accommodation: Choose from a range of options, from budget-friendly guesthouses to luxury resorts.

Transportation:
You can hire a local auto-rickshaw or taxi to travel conveniently in the city.
You may use Uber or Ola for a ride-hailing service.
Photography: The colors, architectural splendor, and serene backwaters of Cochin.
People: Interact with the amiable locals and understand their culture and traditions.

Remember to do:
Research and book in advance: Especially in peak season.
Pack light and comfortable clothing: Suitable for the tropical climate.
Stay hydrated and apply sunscreen: To protect yourself from the sun.
Be respectful of the local culture.

Have a good trip to Cochin!

fields.title: KASARAGOD
fields.content:
The northernmost district of Kerala is often overlooked by the majority of tourists. Kasaragod is however a place which has something of everything from varied cultures, impressive landscapes to life at leisurely pace. Let's plan Day 1
Arrival & Bekal Fort
Morning: Fly into Mangalore International Airport (IXE) or Kannur International Airport (CNN)
Afternoon: Drive to your Kasaragod hotel for check-in.
Evening: Visit the majestic Bekal Fort, one of the largest and best-preserved forts in Kerala. Enjoy the spectacular views of the Arabian Sea.

Day 2: Beaches & Backwaters
Morning: Proceed to Bekal Beach, a pristine beach famous for its golden sands and calm waters.
Afternoon: Take a peaceful backwater cruise. Discover the serene canals, lush green paddy fields, and local villages.
Evening: Savor a mouth-watering seafood dinner at a beachside restaurant.

Day 3: Temples & Culture
Morning: Visit Ananthapura Lake Temple-a unique temple to Lord Vishnu.
Afternoon:  Explore Chandragiri Fort - lesser-known, but with an interesting history
Evening: Participate in the local culture - watch a traditional dance performance (available)

Day 4: Spice Gardens & Departure
Morning:  Visit spice plantation and know about the culture and processing of spices like pepper, cardamom, and cinnamon.
Afternoon: Souvenir shopping time - get spices, handicrafts, and local products.
Evening: Return to Mangalore International Airport (IXE) or Kannur International Airport (CNN).

Food:
You would love the fresh seafood. Enjoy the local food such as Karimeen Pollichathu, a dish in which the fish is baked in banana leaves, and Appam with Idiyappam.
Find some street food stalls and small local eateries serving authentic local fare.
 
Stay: Homestays and budget-friendly options will abound; resort options will also be plentiful.

Local taxis or auto-rickshaws are available for travel within the district.
You may use Ola or Uber, a ride-hailing service.

Photography: Beaches, the magnificent forts, and the serene backwaters are there to be captured.

People: Engage with the locals who are friendly and share their culture and traditions.

Remember to:
Research and book in advance: Peak season
Pack light and comfortable clothing: Suitable for the tropical climate.
Hydrate yourself and apply sunscreen: Protect your skin from the sun.
Observe local cultures and traditions.

Have a great trip to Kasaragod!

fields.title: KANNUR
fields.content:
The most gorgeous district of Kerala, India has a blend of history, culture, and the attraction of seashore.

Day 1: Arrival & St. Angelo Fort
Morning: Board your connecting flight for Kannur International Airport - CNN. Check into your hotel.
Afternoon: Visit the historic 16th-century St. Angelo Fort. Explore the ramparts, bastions, and enjoy panoramic views of the Arabian Sea.
Evening: Relax on Payyambalam Beach, a popular beach known for its golden sands and serene atmosphere.

Day 2: Temples & Backwaters
Morning: Visit the ancient Parassinikkadavu Muthappan Temple, a renowned temple dedicated to Lord Shiva.
Afternoon: Embark on a serene backwater cruise. Enjoy the scenic beauty of the Kerala backwaters, lush green landscapes, and local village life.
Evening: Indulge in a delicious seafood dinner at a beachside restaurant.

Day 3: Spice Gardens & Culture
Morning: Visit a spice plantation and understand the cultivation and processing of spices like pepper, cardamom, and cinnamon.
Afternoon: Explore the colorful local markets where you can find spices, handicrafts, and local products.
Evening: Witness the enthralling Theyyam performance, an ancient ritualistic dance form of Kerala.

Day 4: Beaches & Departure
Morning: Spend some time at Muzhappilangad Drive-in Beach, the longest drive-in beach in India.
Afternoon: Enjoy a relaxing beachside massage or indulge in water sports activities.
Evening: Depart from Kannur International Airport (CNN).

Tips for your Blog:
Food:
Don't miss the delicious seafood! Try local delicacies like Karimeen Pollichathu (fish baked in banana leaf) and Appam with Idiyappam.
Explore local eateries and street food stalls for authentic flavors.

Accommodation: Choose from a range of options, from budget-friendly homestays to luxurious resorts.

Transportation:
Local taxis or autos are available and will be most convenient for in district travel
Ola/Ubers can be availed 

Photography:Take photos of the stunning beaches, the massive forts, the peaceful backwaters
People :Get to engage with the kind-hearted people and interact to know a bit about this different culture as well as other practices.
 
Research and make reservations in advance, especially at peak season times.
Light and very comfortable clothing with suitable tropical comfort.
Hydrate and slather on the sunscreen: Sun protection.
Be respectful of local customs and traditions.

Have a great trip to Kannur!

fields.title: TRAVEL TIPS
fields.content:
You're planning a trip. Whether for a long weekend or a month of backpacking, proper preparation can make the stressful journey seamless. This guide is to equip you with the steps you need to have a smooth and enjoyable travel experience.

1. Determine Your Destination & Budget

Dream Big, But Be Realistic: Where do you really want to go? What are your interests, budget, and travel style?
Research Thoroughly: Deep dive into your destination. Read travel blogs, watch documentaries, and consult guidebooks to get a feel for the culture, climate, and must-see attractions.
Set a Budget: Determine your overall travel budget, including flights, accommodation, transportation, food, activities, and souvenirs.
Consider Travel Seasons: Peak seasons tend to be expensive and crowded. Off-season travel will be cheaper and more authentic.

2. Essential Documents & Travel Insurance

Passport & Visas: Your passport should be valid for at least six months beyond your travel dates. Get any required visas well in advance.
Travel Insurance: Protect yourself from inevitable events such as a medical emergency, flight cancellation, or loss of luggage.

3. Pack Smart & Light

Create a Packing List: Make a list of all the essentials and refer to it as you pack.
Pack Versatile Clothing: Pack clothes that can be mixed and matched to create multiple outfits.
Pack Light: Avoid overpacking. Bring only the essentials and consider packing cubes to maximize space.
Don't Forget the Essentials: Pack chargers, adapters, medications, and a first-aid kit.

4. Book Flights & Accommodation

Book Flights in Advance: The best deals are usually found when booking flights well in advance, especially during peak season. Budget airlines and flexible travel dates can also help save money.
Choose Your Accommodation: Choose accommodation that suits your budget and travel style. Options include hotels, hostels, guesthouses, Airbnb, and camping.
Confirm All Bookings: After making your reservations, be sure to confirm them through e-mail or even by calling them for any possible mishap.

5. Familiarize yourself with the Local Customs & Etiquette

Learn Basic Phrases of Local Language: Learn a few local language phrases such as "hello," "thank you," and "please."
Know Local Customs: Be sure to familiarize yourself with the local customs so you won't attract attention in wrong ways.
Stay Informed: Stay updated about any travel advisories or warnings issued by your country.

6. Plan for Unforeseen Situations

Make Copies of Important Documents: Keep a copy of your passport, visa, travel insurance, and other important documents in a safe place except the original
Let Your Bank Know: Notify your bank about your travel dates to avoid issues while using your cards abroad
Take Basic First Aid: Take a basic first-aid course to be prepared for minor injuries.

7. Live Your Life

Be flexible and prepared to change your plans if necessary.
Embrace the Unexpected: The best travel experiences often come from unexpected events.
Most importantly, have fun! Relax, enjoy the journey, and make some lasting memories.
With these steps, you'll be sure to have a nice, enjoyable, and smooth trip. Remember, the most important aspect of traveling is to be organized, flexible, and open to new adventures!

By following these tips, you can approach your next adventure with confidence and excitement, knowing that you've taken the necessary steps to ensure a smooth and memorable journey.

fields.title: MCLEOD GANJ
fields.content:
A Haven in the Hills

Perched amidst the majestic Dhauladhar Range in Himachal Pradesh, India, McLeod Ganj is a perfect fusion of natural splendor and cultural heritage. This quaint hill station, popularly known as "Little Lhasa," has evolved into a haven for Tibetan exiles and a favorite among travelers looking for serenity, adventure, and a peek into an intriguing culture.

A Weave of Experiences

Cultural Experience:

Tsuglagkhang Complex: Witness the abode of Dalai Lama, serene Tsuglagkhang temple, and being a prime pilgrim center among the Buddhists.
Tibetan Museum: Get knowledgeable about the Tibet culture and historical background by gazing at wonderful collections.
Monasteries: Have a very quiet day with monasteries including Namgyal Monastery and Gyuto Monastery.
Tibetan Market: Delight in the colorful market place where one could get beautiful handicrafts, colorful prayer flags, and Tibet antiquities.

Triund Trek: Though challenging, it is an exhilarating trek to Triund with panoramic views of the Himalayas.
Bhagsu Falls: Enjoy a lovely walk uphill, witnessing Bhagsu Falls, cascading and refreshing with its mist and natural beauty.
Nature Walks: Enjoy the scenic trails and forests surrounding McLeod Ganj and its manifold flora and fauna.

Foodie Delights:
Tibetan Cuisine: Savor authentic Tibetan delicacies such as momos, thukpa, and thenthuk.
Cafes and Restaurants: Enjoy Indian, Continental, and international food at the various cafes and restaurants.

Tips for Your Visit:
Best Time to Visit: March to June and September to November are pleasant.
Accommodation: Budget guesthouses, homestays, and luxury resorts are available.
Dress Modestly: At religious sites.
Bargain: Don't hesitate to bargain at the Tibetan market.
Carry Cash: ATMs are scarce.

McLeod Ganj stands to offer something rich in cultural experience and adventure and peace altogether, be it spiritual solace, breathtaking views, or simply a taste of Tibetan culture - this enchanting hill station can surely cast its spell.

fields.title: MUKTESHWAR
fields.content:
A Piece of Heaven in Uttarakhand

Located atop the lush mountains of Uttarakhand, Mukteshwar is a beautiful hill station situated at an elevation of 2,286 metres. It promises a serene retreat away from the madness of city life. The unspoiled panoramic views of snow-capped Himalayas that surround this lovely hill station ensure that nature enthusiasts and adventure goers have a beautiful time.

Unlocking the Gems of Mukteshwar

Panoramic Scenic Views: The panoramic scenic views are no doubt the attractions of Mukteshwar. From the vantage point, you can watch the majestic view of Nanda Devi, Trishul, and Panchachuli, which offers a breathtakingly beautiful view.

Adventure Activities
Trekking: Explore scenic trails to Chauli Ki Jali, the natural rock formation with a stunning view.
Camping: Camp amidst nature under a starry night sky.
Rock Climbing: Try your hand at rock climbing adventure at designated areas.

Nature's Embrace:
Mukteshwar Temple: Explore the ancient Mukteshwar Temple, which is dedicated to Lord Shiva.
Nature Walks: Take leisurely walks through the lush green forests and absorb the serenity of the surroundings.
Birdwatching: Spot many avian species, including Himalayan birds, in their natural habitat.

Tips for Your Mukteshwar Adventure:
Best Time to Visit: March to June and September to November have pleasant weather.
Accommodation: Cozy homestays, budget-friendly guesthouses, and luxurious resorts are available.
Pack Warm: You never know. Even on those summer days, sunsets make everything cool again
Carry a lot of Cash: If need be, this is where ATM's go shy
Be true to nature; do not litter your surroundings.

As a secluded but beautiful location still waiting to be visited, be it peace or activity or just reformation with Mother Earth, the enthralling Mukteshwar hill station, in one memorable experience.

fields.title: WAYANAD
fields.content:
Tucked deep within the Western Ghats, there lies a forgotten treasure in the state of Kerala, India-Wayanad. This is an idyllic district of scintillating green hills and cascading waterfalls, characterized by rich biodiversity. The breathtaking beauty of natural landscapes is set against the vivid tapestry of cultural heritage.

A Journey Through Verdant Landscapes

The trip to Wayanad began with a beautiful scenic drive on windy roads that pass by tea plantations and spice gardens. Fresh air was fragrant with brewed coffee, mixed with birds' chirps and whatnot.

Must Visit Destinations:

Edakkal Caves: An ancient cave which boasts the early man's life and contains ancient prehistoric carvings that open the gates of history to be discovered by a tourist.
Meenmutty Falls: It is a three-tiered water-fall ideal for a picnic along with a swim.
Banasura Sagar Dam: Asia's second largest earthen dam, with spectacular views and boating possibilities.
Pookode Lake: Freshwater lake with verdant surrounds, perfect for a leisurely walk or boat ride.
Chembra Peak: A good test trek leading to a vantage view from the top of the scenery around.

Beyond the Landscapes: Cultural Immersion

Wayanad is not just a treasure of natural beauty. The district boasts a rich cultural heritage in its tribal communities, traditional art forms, and local cuisine. I had the privilege of visiting a tribal village. The locals received me warmly, and I got to learn some of their unique customs and traditions.

A Gastronomic Delight

No visit to Wayanad is complete without sampling the delicacies. Ranging from the spiciest curries to the tastiest biryanis, the luscious sweets to the soothing beverages, it has everything a gourmet could desire for a delight on his tongue.

A sanctuary for wildlife:

Many different types of flora and fauna can be encountered in Wayanad. The Wayanad Wildlife Sanctuary is home to elephants, tigers, and numerous other species. The jeep safari through the sanctuary was a truly memorable experience.

Traveler's Paradise

Whether you are an adventure-seeker, a nature lover, or a cultural enthusiast, Wayanad has something for everyone. The serene beauty, rich history, and warm hospitality make it the perfect destination for a memorable getaway.

Tips for Travelers:

The best time to visit Wayanad is during the winter months (October to March) when the weather is pleasant.
Carry comfortable shoes and clothing suitable for trekking and outdoor activities.
Respect the local culture and traditions.
Support local businesses and artisans.

fields.title: MALAPPURAM
fields.content:
A district located in the northern part of Kerala, India, is a place of enchanting natural beauty, cultural richness, and historical significance. This destination is known for its lush green hills, cascading waterfalls, and backwaters that offer a unique experience for every kind of traveler.

Some of the must-visit attractions in Malappuram are as follows:

Nilambur

Nilambur teak forests: Learn about the awe-inspiring beauty of the ancient teak forest that was home to many of the world's oldest and largest teaks.
Chundakkara Mosque: Look at the marvelous architecture of this mosque, a masterpiece in itself, dating back hundreds of years
Adyanthrathu waterfalls: Adyanthrathu waterfalls make for a stunning picnic spot in the heart of Kerala.

Malappuram town:

Ponnani: The famous coastal town in Malappuram, associated with historicity and beauty through its beaches.
Experience the ancient Ayurvedic treatments and therapies at the well-known Kottakkal Arya Vaidya Sala.

Vengara:

Pazhassi Raja Museum: Explore the biography and rule of Pazhassi Raja, the legendary freedom fighter in Pazhassi Raja Museum.
Thusharagiri Waterfalls: Enjoy the stunning views of Thusharagiri Waterfalls, a lacing waterfall with green foliage cover.

Manjeri:

Kadalundi Bird Sanctuary: Visit Kadalundi Bird Sanctuary, the haven for all bird lovers and see a large number of different species of birds.
Tanur: Take a visit to the coastal town of Tanur, famous for its fishing harbor and seafood.

Malappuram Tourist Activities:

Trekking: Go on a trek through the green hills and valleys of Malappuram.
Waterfalls: Visit several waterfalls that include Thusharagiri, Adyanthrathu, and Soochipara.
Backwater Cruises: Have a rejuvenated backwater cruise in Malappuram over the serene waterways.
Ayurveda: Some of the many Ayurvedic resorts in the region will work their rejuvenation magic upon you.
Local cuisine: Seafood, rice dishes, and Kerala's traditional sweets make for sumptuous feasting.


Traveler's tips:

The winters (October to March) are the best time to visit Malappuram.
Carry light shoes for trekking and exploring the region.
Pack lightweight clothes for the warmest time and heavy clothes for the cold season.
Learn a few basic Malayalam phrases to make your tour much more enjoyable.
Respect local culture and traditions.

Malappuram is an amalgamation of natural beauty, cultural richness, and historical significance. This region offers lush green hills, cascading waterfalls, and serene backwaters, making it a must-visit destination for any traveler seeking an authentic Kerala experience.

fields.title: PALAKKAD
fields.content:
Palakkad is a land of palm trees and paddy fields. It is a hidden gem in Kerala, with its historical significance, cultural richness, and breathtaking landscapes. Palakkad offers a unique experience for every traveler.

Day 1: Exploring the Historical Wonders

Begin with the visit to Palakkad Fort, popularly known as Tipu's Fort. The construction of this fort is credited to Hyder Ali in the 18th century, and it represents the glorious past of this region. One can learn much about its rich history while observing the architectural details of the fort.
Visit Vadakkanthara Temple- A very old temple dedicated to Goddess Bhagavathy and take blessings amidst traditional Kerala architecture and spiritual ambience.
Explore the Jain Heritage of Palakkad at the Jain Temple of Jainimedu. This beautiful serene temple stands testimony to the diverse religious heritage of the region.

Day 2: Getting close to Mother Nature

Malampuzha Dam and Gardens: Get a retreat into the bosom of nature at the Malampuzha Dam and Gardens. Enjoy a boat ride in the peaceful lake, stroll through the lovely garden, and see the uniqueness of the rock garden.
Silent Valley National Park: Get ready for an adventure to the Silent Valley National Park, which is a biodiversity hotspot. Trek through the dense forests, rare flora, and fauna, and enjoy the peaceful silence of nature.
Dhoni Waterfalls: Visit the cascading beauty of Dhoni Waterfalls. Trek through the lush green forests to the falls and experience a refreshing swim in the cool waters.

Day 3: Cultural Immersion

Kalpathy Heritage Village: Step into the past in the Kalpathy Heritage Village, a traditional Brahmin settlement. Walk along the narrow streets, appreciate old-world architecture, and experience unique culture in the village.
Chittur Kavu Devi Temple: Attend the colorfully vibrant processions and functions at the annual festival of the Chittur Kavu Devi Temple. Enjoy yourself in the brilliant processions, folk music, and dance presentations.
Ottapalam: Visit the small town of Ottapalam to experience its cultural heritage and scenery. Visit some of the oldest temples, the busy markets, and the native way of living.

More Advice for Your Stay

Best Time to Visit: The best time to visit Palakkad is during the winter months from October to March when the climate is pleasant.
Accommodation: Palakkad offers various accommodation options ranging from budget-friendly guesthouses to luxurious resorts.
Food: Try the local delicacies of Palakkad such as Palakkadan Matta rice, Puttu, Appam, and Fish Curry.
Transport: Palakkad is well-connected by road and rail. One can hire a taxi or use a bus to visit the district.

Palakkad is the destination that promises a perfect combination of history, nature, and culture. For a history buff, a nature lover, or a culture enthusiast, Palakkad has its own share to offer. Pack your bags, and get on a journey to this enchanting land of Kerala.

fields.title: THRISSUR
fields.content:
Thrissur- also known as the Cultural Capital of Kerala- is a city overflowing with history, vibrant festivals, and breathtaking natural beauty.

Day 1

Morning: Start with a visit to Vadakkunnathan Temple, which is one of the oldest Hindu temples dedicated to Lord Shiva. Enjoy the traditional Kerala architecture and 'murals' of this heritage site.
Afternoon: Visit Thrissur Zoo and State Museum, full of varied animals and artifacts to signify the rich history and culture in that particular region.
Evening: Stroll around Thekkinkadu Maidan, a huge ground encasing the Vadakkunnathan Temple. Just relax and absorb the lively ambiance.

Day 2

Morning: Embark on a scenic drive to the breathtaking Athirapally Waterfalls, often referred to as the "Niagara of India." Enjoy the cascading waters and lush greenery.
Afternoon: Visit the nearby Vazhachal Falls, another stunning waterfall surrounded by dense forests.
Evening: Relax and unwind at Peechi Dam, a picturesque reservoir offering boating and other recreational activities.

Day 3

Morning: Immerse yourself in the world of traditional performing arts at Kerala Kalamandalam, a renowned institution for Kathakali and other classical art forms.
Afternoon: Explore the Shakthan Thampuran Palace, a historical palace showcasing Kerala's royal heritage.
Evening: Witness a mesmerizing Kathakali performance or enjoy a traditional Kerala dinner.

Food:
Must-tries: Appam, Puttu, Fish Curry, Payasam, and Sadhya (a vegetarian feast).
Where to eat: Try the local restaurants around Vadakkunnathan Temple or explore the food stalls at Thekkinkadu Maidan.

Accommodation:
Options: Hotels near the city center, guesthouses in quieter areas
Book in advance: Especially in peak season or during Thrissur Pooram.

Transport:
Local travel: Auto-rickshaws available
Exploring around: Consider renting a car or hiring a taxi for day trips.

Shopping:
What to buy: Traditional handicrafts, silk sarees, spices.
Where to shop: Look around the markets nearby the temple or stop by a local mall.

Other recommendations:
Best time to visit: Winters, from October to February.
Dress modestly: For any religious site.
Bring water: Drink plenty and be hydrated, more so when hot.
Learn a few words in Malayalam: It would make the experience even more enjoyable
Be prepared for crowds: Thrissur is one of those places that get populated more especially during festivals.

fields.title: ERNAKULAM
fields.content:
Ernakulam is the vibrant heart of Kochi, and it has history, culture, and natural beauty all together in a blend.

Day 1
Morning: Start with the exploration at Fort Kochi, a historic area with remnants of colonial architecture, including the iconic Chinese fishing nets.
Afternoon: Mattancherry Palace, also known as the Dutch Palace, shows Kerala murals and historical artifacts.
Evening: Stroll down Jew Town, a long narrow street lined with old antique shops and the historic Paradesi Synagogue.

Day 2
Morning: Visit the Kerala Kathakali Centre to learn about the style of local dance form Kathakali.
Afternoon: Take a ride by ferry to Vypin Island, and finally enjoy the stretch of Cherai Beach.
Evening: Leisurely walk down Marine Drive - a scenic promenade with beautiful backwater views.

Day 3
Morning: Enjoy an excursion to Athirapally Waterfalls, also called "Niagara of India".
Afternoon: Do a tour around Vazhachal Falls, which are another water falls surrounded by deep green cover
Evening: Return back to Ernakulam. Here, treat yourselves to mouthwatering sea foods at local eateries
 
Food:  
Must-haves: Seafood (mainly Karimeen Pollichathu), Appam, Puttu, Kerala meals, and local snacks.
Where to eat: Try restaurants in Fort Kochi, Mattancherry, and Marine Drive. Never be afraid to try local-scale eateries.

Accommodation:
Choices: Guesthouses from budget to luxury hotels, especially in Fort Kochi and Ernakulam city.
Book ahead: Recommended, especially high season.

Transportation:
Local travel: Auto-rickshaws, bus, and ferries are also available.
Explore around: Rent a car or hire a taxi for day trips. Ferry is an excellent way to reach different islands.

Shopping:
What to buy: Spices, handicrafts, Kathakali masks, and souvenirs.
Where to shop: Jew Town, Broadway market, and the local shops in Fort Kochi.

Other tips:
Best time to visit: Winter months (October to March) for pleasant weather.
Respectful attire: Dress modestly when visiting religious sites.
Be prepared for crowds: Especially in popular tourist areas like Fort Kochi.
Bargaining: Common practice in local markets.
Currency: Indian Rupees (INR). ATMs are widely available.

fields.title: IDUKKI
fields.content:
Idukki, nestled in the Western Ghats of Kerala, is a haven for nature lovers and adventure seekers.  

Day 1

Morning: Start your day with a trek to Anamudi Peak, the highest peak in South India (requires permission and guides). Or, for a less strenuous option, hike to a viewpoint like Top Station for breathtaking panoramic views.
Afternoon: Explore the Eravikulam National Park, home to the endangered Nilgiri Tahr. (Note: Park access is limited and requires advance booking).
Evening: Relax amidst the tea plantations of Munnar, enjoying the cool mountain air and the fragrant aroma of tea.

Day 2

Morning: Visit the majestic Idukki Dam, one of the world's largest arch dams. (Check for visiting hours and restrictions).
Afternoon: Chase waterfalls! Visit Athirapally Falls (technically in Thrissur district, but easily accessible from Idukki), or explore closer options like Vazhachal Falls or smaller cascades within Idukki.
Evening: Enjoy a boat ride on Anayirangal Dam, surrounded by lush greenery, and perhaps even observe some elephants.

Day 3

Morning: Visit a spice plantation with information about the cultivation of the spices, including cardamom, pepper, and cloves.
Afternoon: Explore Vagamon - an adventurous hill station that is a haven for paragliding and trekking.
Evening: Spend a quiet evening in a homestay or resort, soaking in the peacefulness of the mountains.

Food:
Must-try: Spicy Kerala curries, fresh seafood if you are near the coast, Appam, Puttu, and local delicacies prepared with spices grown in the region.
Where to eat: Try local restaurants in Munnar, or smaller eateries in towns like Painavu and Kattappana.

Accommodation:
Options: From budget-friendly homestays to luxurious resorts, especially in Munnar and Vagamon.
Book in advance: Absolutely, especially during peak season and holidays.

Transportation:
Local travel: Auto-rickshaws are easily available in towns.
Exploring around: The most convenient way to explore this hilly district, including the remote places is by hiring a car or jeep.

Things to pack:
Comfortable shoes: Hiking around and wandering
Layers of clothing: Weather is very unpredictable up in the mountains.
Rain gear: Idukki experiences moderate amount of rainfall.
Insect repellent: Especially if you are going to spend plenty of time outdoors.

Other Tips:
Pleasant Weather October to February Best time to visit
When visiting religious places Respectful dresses Winding road areas If one suffers from Motion sickness Carry all the cash on your person in hand. Check permits if any needed for a trek to the peak of Anamudi, or for visitations to restricted places.

fields.title: KILIMANJARO: MAJESTY AND MYSTICAL
fields.content:
There are songs that stay with you long after the music fades. They evoke memories, emotions, and sometimes, even transport you to another place.  "Kilimanjaro," the iconic song from Rajinikanth's film Enthiran, is one such example.  The song, with its catchy beats and vibrant visuals, is a celebration of the majestic Mount Kilimanjaro. It's impossible to hear the song without picturing the snow-capped peak, the lush greenery, and the breathtaking scenery.  And it's true: Kilimanjaro is so much more than just a mountain. It's an adventure waiting to happen.

Kilimanjaro. The name itself evokes images of a snow-capped giant, a solitary peak rising improbably from the African savanna. More than just a mountain, Kilimanjaro is a symbol of challenge, beauty, and the delicate balance between nature and human ambition. Its imposing presence dominates the Tanzanian landscape, attracting climbers, researchers, and dreamers from around the globe, all drawn to its enduring allure. The mountain's grandeur stems from its unique formation, but its appeal goes far beyond the summit.

Kilimanjaro has evolved into a globally renowned tourist destination, attracting adventurers, nature enthusiasts, and cultural explorers. From thrilling wildlife encounters to refreshing dips in hidden oases, prepare to be amazed by the sheer variety and beauty of this incredible destination!

Conquering Kibo (and Your Fears):

Let's start with the obvious: Mount Kibo, the highest peak of Kilimanjaro, is a magnetic draw for climbers worldwide. The feeling of standing on the summit, overlooking a vast expanse of Africa, is undoubtedly a life-altering experience.  Countless climbers have described intense challenges, breathtaking views, and an unparalleled sense of accomplishment. There are various routes to choose from, each with its own unique challenges and landscapes, so do your research and choose the one that best suits your fitness level and experience. But even if you don't reach the summit, simply gazing at Kibo from below is an awe-inspiring experience.

Safari Dreams:

Speaking of awe-inspiring, no trip to Tanzania is complete without a Tanzanian Safari. Fortunately, the Kilimanjaro region is your gateway to some of the most incredible wildlife viewing opportunities in the world. From the iconic Serengeti National Park to the lesser-known but equally rewarding Tarangire National Park, get ready to witness the "Big Five" in their natural habitat.  Imagine herds of elephants grazing against the backdrop of ancient baobab trees, lions, giraffes, zebras – the sheer abundance of wildlife is truly humbling, and the knowledgeable guides will enrich your experience with fascinating insights.

Oasis of Calm:

After the dust and excitement of the safari, you'll need a place to relax and unwind. Look no further than the Kikuletwa Hot springs, often referred to as the "Chemka Hot Springs." Imagine turquoise, crystal-clear water surrounded by lush fig trees, with Kilimanjaro looming in the distance. This is paradise! The water is warm and inviting, perfect for a refreshing swim and a chance to rejuvenate your muscles after a long day of adventure.

Waterfalls and Coffee:

For a different kind of refreshing experience, head to the Materuni Waterfalls. This stunning cascade is located in the foothills of Kilimanjaro, nestled amidst a vibrant coffee plantation. The hike to the falls takes you through lush rainforest, offering glimpses of local village life and the opportunity to learn about the coffee-making process from bean to cup. The reward? A breathtaking waterfall cascading into a cool, refreshing pool.

Tranquil Lake Chala:

Looking for a peaceful escape? Lake Chala is your answer. This stunning crater lake, located on the border between Tanzania and Kenya, boasts incredibly clear, deep blue waters surrounded by steep crater walls. It's a haven for birdwatchers, with a diverse array of avian species inhabiting the surrounding forests.

Immerse Yourself in Maasai Culture:

Finally, no trip to Kilimanjaro is complete without immersing yourself in the local culture. Olpopongi - Maasai Cultural Village & Museum offers a unique opportunity to learn about the traditions and way of life of the Maasai people. You'll be welcomed into a traditional Maasai village, where you can observe their daily routines, learn about their customs, and even participate in traditional dances.

So, there you have it! Kilimanjaro isn't just about conquering a mountain; it's about embarking on an incredible journey through diverse landscapes, encountering breathtaking wildlife, and immersing yourself in the rich culture of Tanzania. From thrilling safaris to relaxing hot springs, there's something for everyone in this amazing corner of the world. So, pack your bags, grab your sense of adventure, and prepare to be amazed by the magic of Kilimanjaro! What are you waiting for? Your Tanzanian adventure awaits!

fields.title: UNVEILING THE SOUL OF GOA
fields.content:
Goa conjures up visions of sun-bathed beaches, waving palms, and the thumping rhythm of trance music. That these are admittedly a part of Goa's fascination is undeniable; scratch the surface, however, and you find a rich texture interwoven with interesting history, Portuguese flavour, pulsating culture, and a surprising cache of off-beat gems. My recent holiday in Goa served to confirm all this, with me being struck by its rich diversity. Follow me here in a glimpse into my Goan sojourn, beyond the beaten tourist path.
Naturally, no visit to Goa is complete without the experience of its famous beaches. Baga Beach, famous for its vibrancy, was a sensory feast. The colorful shacks, the crowded throngs, and the adrenaline of water sports created an electric vibe that was difficult to ignore. I spent an afternoon relishing succulent seafood at a beach shack, basking in the sun and the infectious happiness of the surroundings.
From the lively seafront, I walked into the core of Old Goa, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, transporting myself back in time amidst majestic churches and cathedrals. The Basilica of Bom Jesus, containing the holy remains of St. Francis Xavier, was an utterly breathtaking experience. Its baroque architecture, peaceful ambiance, and sheer historical relevance left me with no words to say. As I walked through the complex, I could feel a tangible sense of the past, envisioning the pilgrims who had traversed these same routes for centuries.
Stepping out of the seriousness of Old Goa, I was strolling through the quaint streets of Fontainhas, Goa's Latin Quarter. This quaint neighbourhoods, with its colourful Portuguese architecture, brightly painted houses, and winding narrow streets, was like entering another world. I spent hours just wandering around, taking in the elaborately detailed architecture of the buildings, basking in the ambiance, and taking hundreds of photos. The scent of fresh bread and the melodies of Fado music from a local cafe made for this historic enclave's own special charm.
For a glimpse of Goan bustle and activity, I went to the legendary Anjuna Market, a Wednesday staple. The market was a riot of colours, noises, and odours. There were hand-knitted garments and jewelry to spices and mementos - the number of things on display was too many to count. I negotiated prices with the vendors, tried some local delicacies, and loved the cacophonous, exuberant energy of this market. It is an ideal location to look for unusual trinkets and experience the true essence of Goa.
Talking of history, a trip to Old Goa is a must for every history buff. Aside from the Basilica, the remains of the Church of St. Augustine and the Se Cathedral provide a glimpse into Goa's glorious colonial history. Although time has worn them down, these architectural marvels remain as remnants of a bygone era, reverberating with stories of Portuguese rule and religious fervor.
For another sort of thrill, I went ahead and tried my hand at the Big Daddy Casino on the Mandovi River. The experience was certainly glamorous and thrilling, with a lively vibe and plenty of games to choose from. Though I didn't get rich overnight, the whole experience was something to remember and gave my vacation a touch of Vegas-style excitement.
Seeking a more tranquil escape, I took a ferry to Chorão Island, home to the Salim Ali Bird Sanctuary. This placid island offered a welcome respite from the bustling beaches and offered a chance to connect with nature. I took a boat tour through the mangroves, spotting a variety of birds and enjoying the peaceful atmosphere. It's a birdwatcher's paradise and a perfect destination for those seeking a more laid-back Goan experience.
Back in Panjim, I went to the Immaculate Conception Church, which stands majestically on top of a hill overlooking the city. Its spotless white exterior and imposing building make it a landmark that cannot be missed. The ascent to the top was rewarded with breathtaking panoramic views of Panjim and the surrounding countryside.
For even more stunning views, I went to Altinho Hill, another viewpoint providing inspiring views of Panjim and the Mandovi River. The peaceful environment and panoramic view made it an ideal place for reflection and appreciation of the beauty of Goa. A glimpse into the religious past of Goa took me to the Archbishop's Palace, a majestic and heavy-looking building that was the residence of the Archbishop of Goa. Though not usually open to tourists for detailed tours, even viewing its exterior design provides information about the historical and religious importance of this building.
Finally aware of the historical treasure that whispers stories of the past. Beyond the crowded beaches is Aguada Fort, a stunning 17th-century Portuguese fort standing proudly atop a hill overlooking the Arabian Sea. A recent day excursion to this famous landmark provided an intriguing insight into Goa's rich history, an experience that combined scenic coastal scenery with an in-depth exploration of colonial history. I was mesmerized to learn about its fascinating story and the dramatic scenery that turns it into an unmissable stop on any visit to Goa.
My visit to Goa was an eye-opener. It was not beaches and parties only; it was a journey into history, culture, and infectious local life. From the religious tranquility of Old Goa to the colorful chaos of Anjuna Market, Goa presented a wide variety of experiences that kept me enthralled. I departed with an added appreciation for this complex destination, looking forward to returning and unearthing more of its lesser-known secrets. So the next time you plan a visit to Goa, don't just stop at the beaches and instead go on to find the rich brocade waiting to be uncovered. You won't be disappointed.

fields.title: KOTTAYAM
fields.content:
Kottayam, situated in Kerala, India, is a combination of backwaters, hills, and culture. 

Day 1: Backwater Bliss

Morning: Reach Kottayam and proceed to the backwaters. Alleppey (Alappuzha) is well connected from Kottayam and a favorite spot for houseboat cruises. Board a traditional houseboat (kettuvallam) and sail through the peaceful canals, witnessing the green paddy fields, rice paddies, and local villages.
Afternoon: Proceed on your backwater cruise. Have a sumptuous Kerala lunch on board the houseboat. Watch the various bird species and even attempt to fish.
Evening: Leave the houseboat and check into your Kottayam hotel. Have a leisurely evening. You might visit the local market or indulge in a traditional Kerala dinner.

Day 2: Hills and History

Morning: Spend time at the Thirunakkara Mahadeva Temple, an ancient and important temple in Kottayam for its murals and structure.
Afternoon: Take a trip to Vagamon, a hill station famous for its beauty, adventure sports, and climate. Go paragliding, trekking, or just relax and enjoy the splendor.
Evening: Return to Kottayam. If time allows, spend time at the Kottayam Cheriapally, an old church with pretty architecture.

Day 3: Nature and Culture

Morning: Go to the Kumarakom Bird Sanctuary, a bird-watcher's paradise. Spot various migratory as well as local birds in the wild. A boat tour of the sanctuary can be arranged.
Afternoon: Visit the markets for shopping of spices, handicrafts, and souvenirs. Being a region where rubber is mainly cultivated, Kottayam may acquaint you with the growth of rubber.
Evening: Depart from Kottayam.

Additional Activities

Athirapally and Vazhachal Waterfalls: If you have time, take a day trip to these impressive waterfalls, although they are somewhat remote.
Illikkal Kallu: A rare rock formation in the upper ranges of Kottayam. It involves a strenuous trek.
